hadiths.english_translation: It is narrated that Sulaiman ibn Dawud would rely upon an old woman, and whenever he slept during the day, a white serpent would come and ward off (flies/insects) from his face.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn ibn Muhammad ibn Ja'far al-Shibaani
narrators.alternative_names: al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath

narrators.name: Ibrahim ibn Fahd
narrators.full_name: Ibrahim ibn Fahd ibn Hakim ibn Ibrahim ibn Qudamah ibn Mahan al-Saji
reliabilityIssues: No clear reliability grade in sources
narrators.alternative_names: al-Basri, Abu Ishaq al-Saji, Abu Ishaq

narrators.name: Adam
narrators.full_name: Adam ibn Abi Iyas ibn Taghlib al-Basri
reliabilityIssues: Some scholars considered him Saduq with weak memory

narrators.name: Hammad ibn Salamah
narrators.full_name: Hammad ibn Salamah ibn Dinar al-Azdi al-Basri
reliabilityIssues: Mudallis (type 2) - but generally accepted due to reliability
His 'an transmissions from well-known teachers are acceptable

narrators.name: Abu Imran al-Jawni
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Malik ibn Nafi' Abu Imran al-Jawni

narrators.name: Nawf al-Bikali
narrators.full_name: Nawf ibn Tabari Abu Abdillah al-Bikali
reliabilityIssues: Saduq status - some hadith scholars accepted him with caution

chainIssues: Multiple 'an transmissions (عَنْ) from Nawf al-Bikali onwards may indicate indirect transmission
Transmission term variation: Hammad uses 'na' while Abu Imran uses 'an
Muhammad ibn al-Husayn (first narrator) is unknown (Majhul) which weakens the entire chain

potential_issues.issue: First narrator (Muhammad ibn al-Husayn al-Shibaani) is Majhul (unknown)
potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the hadith as the entire chain depends on the reliability of the collector/first narrator. An unknown narrator at the beginning of a chain undermines the validity of the entire transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Ibrahim ibn Fahd al-Saji is Majhul al-Hal (unknown status)
potential_issues.impact: The second narrator in the chain has no documented reliability record, further compromising chain integrity.

potential_issues.issue: Adam is graded as Saduq with weak memory according to some scholars
potential_issues.impact: While Saduq narrators are generally acceptable, Adam's memory issues may affect accuracy in transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Hammad ibn Salamah is a known mudallis (type 2), though generally reliable
potential_issues.impact: His use of 'na' (direct narration) mitigates the mudallis concern, as direct transmission terms from a reliable mudallis are generally accepted.

potential_issues.issue: Nawf al-Bikali's 'an transmission from Abu Imran creates a gap in the chain
potential_issues.impact: The indirect transmission ('an) at this point may indicate a missing link in the narration pathway, particularly concerning for late tabi'i narrations.

Topics: Incident of the white serpent protecting Sulaiman
Story of a Prophet and extraordinary occurrences

hadiths.english_translation: Regarding His (Allah's) saying 'in kindness' (Surah Sad, verse 36), he said: 'Kindness means the good/pleasant wind.'

chainIssues: First narrator (Muhammad ibn al-Husayn) is unknown, weakening the entire chain
Multiple Saduq narrators throughout the chain (Adam, Warqa, Ibn Abi Najih, Mujahid)
Use of 'an (عَنِ/عَنْ) from Ibn Abi Najih and Mujahid creates transmission ambiguity
This is a tafsir (Quranic interpretation) likely representing scholarly commentary rather than a marfu' hadith

potential_issues.issue: First narrator Muhammad ibn al-Husayn is Majhul (unknown)
potential_issues.impact: An unknown collector significantly weakens the chain's reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple Saduq narrators in succession (Adam, Warqa, Ibn Abi Najih, Mujahid)
potential_issues.impact: While individually acceptable, a chain with multiple Saduq narrators reduces overall authenticity grading.

potential_issues.issue: Transmission term variation - 'an transmissions appear without documented liqa' (meeting)
potential_issues.impact: The 'an terms from Ibn Abi Najih and Mujahid may indicate indirect transmission or gaps.

potential_issues.issue: This appears to be Quranic exegesis (tafsir) rather than a marfu' hadith
potential_issues.impact: Tafsir transmissions have different authenticity standards than hadith, and reliability standards may differ.

Topics: Quranic interpretation of Surah Sad verse 36

hadiths.english_translation: Regarding His (Allah's) saying 'wherever it came' (Surah Sad, verse 36), he said: 'Wherever he willed.' And through its chain, regarding His saying 'Grant to us' (Surah Sad, verse 39), he said: 'Give,' and 'Or withhold without reckoning' (Surah Sad, verse 39), he said: 'Without restriction/difficulty.'

potential_issues.issue: This is clearly Quranic exegesis (tafsir) rather than a prophetic hadith

hadiths.english_translation: The devil who was sent (to test) Ayyub was named Masut.

hadiths.english_translation: Regarding His (Allah's) saying 'and Dhu al-Kifl' (Surah Sad, verse 48), he said: 'Dhu al-Kifl was a righteous man, but not a prophet. He pledged to a prophet that he would take care of his people and judge between them with justice, and for that he was named Dhu al-Kifl (one with a portion).'
